channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: McDonald’s Opens in Vietnam, Bringing Big Mac to Fans of Banh Mi
item.description: The fast-food giant is opening its first restaurant in the country, which some see as one of Asia’s last consumer markets with significant untapped potential.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE IVES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Supporters Call for Investigation Into Death of Chinese Activist’s Father
item.description: The authorities in Shandong Province told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procurator’s office building in the city of Qufu.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Xue Mingkai, whose father, Xue Fushun, died under disputed circumstances.

item.title: Guatemalan Court Upholds Top Prosecutor's Ouster
item.description: Guatemala's Supreme Court on Friday upheld its ruling that the country's crusading attorney general must step down in May, seven months before her term was set to end, drawing complaints from human rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 2 Former Premiers Try to Use Tokyo Election to Rally Public Against Nuclear Power
item.description: Former Prime Ministers Morihiro Hosokawa and Junichiro Koizumi are trying to turn the election for Tokyo governor on Sunday into a referendum on the future of nuclear power in Japan.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Yoichi Masuzoe is the governing party’s candidate for Tokyo governor.

item.title: U.S. Prisoner in North Korea Gets Consular Visit
item.description: A Swedish diplomat visited Kenneth Bae, who has been imprisoned in North Korea for more than a year, his family reported, as speculation grew over potential talks to free him.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Deception Foils Attempt to Hijack Turkish Jet to Sochi
item.description: Turkish officials said a passenger claiming a bomb was aboard wanted the aircraft diverted to Sochi, but it landed in Istanbul and he was arrested.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: So Many Bribes, a Greek Official Can’t Recall Them All
item.description: The testimony by a deputy in the Defense Ministry, if accurate, illustrates how arms makers from Germany, France, Sweden and Russia passed out payoffs to sell Greece weaponry that it could ill afford.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Greek Defense Ministry paid more than $4 billion for submarines that sit virtually abandoned in a shipyard outside Athens.

item.title: Leaked Recordings Lay Bare E.U. and U.S. Divisions in Goals for Ukraine
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany criticized an assistant secretary of state’s undiplomatic comment on European efforts to resolve the political crisis in Ukraine.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany issued a sharp statement denouncing the American diplomat's remarks on the political crisis in Kiev.

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Government Deletes Drawings, Posted Online, of a Secret Spying Site
item.description: The government of Canada on Friday removed detailed architectural drawings of a secret electronic eavesdropping station that had been posted online.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Rules to Aid Asylum-Seeking Refugees Are Called Security Threat
item.description: Republican lawmakers assailed new exemptions from antiterrorism laws the Obama administration issued this week for war zone refugees seeking to come to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON

item.title: World Briefing: China: Tibetan Dies in Act of Protest
item.description: A Tibetan man died after setting himself on fire in an act of protest against the Chinese government, according to information released Friday by Free Tibet, an advocacy group.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Muslims Flee
item.description: Thousands of Muslims protected by Chadian soldiers fled the capital, Bangui, in a mass exodus on Friday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Despite Signs of Progress, Security Issues Rise in Tunisia
item.description: Security has become the most pressing issue in Tunisia as the country tries to move forward with its democratic transition and rescue its still declining economy.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house in Tunis after a police shootout this week left seven gunmen and a National Guardsman dead.

item.title: The Lede: Journalist Badly Wounded by Flare During Rio Protest
item.description: Video and photographs recorded during clashes in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday showed a Brazilian cameraman being struck in the head by an explosive device.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Santiago Andrade, a cameraman for a Brazilian network, was struck in the head by an explosive device while covering clashes between protesters and the police in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday.

item.title: Protests Over Government and Economy Roil Bosnia
item.description: Unemployed youths, disgruntled workers and others set fire to buildings in Sarajevo, the capital, and across the country on a fourth day of protests.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Antigovernment demonstrators clashed with police officers in Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In Left-Leaning Norway, Its Wealthy ‘Fox’ Gleefully Swings to the Right
item.description: Olav Thon, a Norwegian billionaire, made his fortune with furs but dresses plainly, and supports the political right in a welfare system.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Kyrre Lien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Of young Norwegians spoiled by the welfare system, Olav Thon says, “You can’t feed a cat with cream and food in the kitchen and expect him to go catch mice.”

item.title: Taliban and Government Imperil Gains for Afghan Women, Advocates Say
item.description: Advocates say troubling signs lie in President Hamid Karzai’s talks with the Taliban and in pending legislation.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Advocates for women in Afghanistan see proposed laws and violent attacks as signs of an effort to diminish the status of women.

item.title: The Lede: Protesters Sack Government Offices Across Bosnia
item.description: As protesters fed up with economic and political stagnation sacked government buildings in cities across Bosnia on Friday, journalists and bloggers shared images and firsthand accounts of the unrest on social networks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Egyptian-American Filmmaker Captures Cairo’s Arab Spring
item.description: Few people in Egypt have seen “The Square,” an Oscar-nominated documentary about the Arab Spring uprising there, but those who have are mostly unhappy about it.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL-SHEIKH
item.media:description: A scene from the documentary “The Square” with Khalid Abdalla, who is an activist in Egypt as well as an actor.

item.title: Scores Detained in Russia Before Olympic Ceremony
item.description: Russian authorities detained at least 61 people on Friday for holding unauthorized protests, underscoring the government’s efforts to stifle dissent.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: The Lede: Defenders of SodaStream Confuse Boycotts of Israeli Settlements With Movement to Boycott Israel
item.description: The antipoverty group Oxfam rejected claims that it has called for a boycott of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Without Scotland, Premier Says, Britain Would Be Less ‘Great’
item.description: The British prime minister appealed to Scottish voters to reject independence in a referendum that will be held in September.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: The British prime minister, David Cameron, speaking in east London on Friday.

item.title: Olympics Opening Ceremony Offers Fanfare for a Reinvented Russia
item.description: After seven years of building to the opening of the Sochi Games, the message of Friday’s over-the-top ceremony was simply this: In a big way, Russia is back.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dancers performed in a segment entitled at "Time Forward!/Suprematic Ballet."

item.title: Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
item.description: The opening ceremony of the 2014 Winter Olympics took place at Fisht Olympic Stadium in Sochi, Russia.

item.title: Brain-Dead, a Canadian Woman Remains a Silent Partner Awaiting Birth
item.description: The family of Robyn Benson, who sustained a fatal brain hemorrhage, hopes her fetus will mature enough to be delivered.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Dylan and Robyn Benson on their wedding day last year. She has been kept on life support.
